question: Does activation of the inhibitory MHC I receptor Ly49Q prevent neutrophil polarization? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Here, we show that an inhibitory MHC I receptor, Ly49Q, was crucial for the swift polarization of and tissue infiltration by neutrophils.
content.source_2: In murine bone marrow–derived neutrophils, engagement of Ly49Q with agonistic antibodies diminished chemokine-induced front–rear asymmetry, effectively preventing polarization and subsequent migration into inflamed tissues.
content.source_3: We propose that Ly49Q is pivotal in switching neutrophils to their polarized morphology and rapid migration upon inflammation, through its spatiotemporal regulation of membrane rafts and raft-associated signaling molecules.
content.source_4: By constraining membrane raft dynamics, active Ly49Q limited the assembly of polarity complexes at the leading edge, resulting in reduced neutrophil polarization during acute inflammation.
